title: Understanding the Formation Constant
text: The formation constant, Kf, is a measure of the stability of the complex ML2. A large Kf value indicates that the complex is very stable and that most of the metal M will be in the form of ML2.

title: Approximate Mass Balance
text: Since Kf is large, we can assume that almost all of the metal M is bound as ML2. This means that the concentration of free M is very small compared to the initial concentration of M.

title: Using the Formation Constant
text: The formation constant Kf is given by the equation: $$Kf=\frac{[ML2]}{[ML2] {[ML2]}^2}$$. Since [ML2] is approximately equal to the initial concentration of M, you can use this equation to solve for [M].

title: Calculate [M]
text: Using the equation $$Kf=\frac{[ML2]}{[ML2] {[ML2]}^2}$$, and knowing that [ML2] is approximately $$0.0100$$ M and [L] is $$0.0500$$ M, solve for [M].

title: Calculating pM
text: Once you have calculated [M], you can find pM using the formula $$pM=-log10([M])$$.

title: Calculate pM
text: Using the value of [M] you calculated, find pM using the formula $$pM=-log10([M])$$.
